meta.description: 133 computable glaze properties from Unity Molecular Formula (UMF). Every calculation runs in real-time — no databases, no internet lookups. Math derived from published glass science, ceramic engineering, and physical chemistry literature (1912–2018).

properties.label: Li₂O
properties.whatItIs: Lithium oxide moles in the Unity Molecular Formula. Direct readout of the Li₂O content.
properties.whyUseful: Most powerful flux per mole. Lowers COE, promotes gloss, reduces viscosity dramatically. Small ionic radius = high field strength = fast melter. A little goes a long way. Map it to find the sweet spot between flux power and cost.

properties.label: Na₂O
properties.whatItIs: Sodium oxide moles in the Unity Molecular Formula. The #1 cause of crazing.
properties.whyUseful: Strong flux, raises COE significantly more than any other oxide. Primary alkali in most glazes. Mapping Na₂O shows exactly where formulas have dangerous alkali concentrations.

properties.label: K₂O
properties.whatItIs: Potassium oxide moles in the Unity Molecular Formula.
properties.whyUseful: Flux with slightly lower COE impact than Na₂O. Promotes smoother, less runny melt. Tends to produce softer, warmer surfaces. Map to compare soda vs potash balance across recipes.

properties.label: MgO
properties.whatItIs: Magnesium oxide moles in UMF. A divalent flux that modifies the glass network less aggressively than alkalis.
properties.whyUseful: Promotes matte surfaces with a buttery smooth feel. Low COE contribution. High-temperature flux. Map to find where satiny mattes develop.

properties.label: CaO
properties.whatItIs: Calcium oxide moles in UMF. The workhorse flux at cone 6 and above.
properties.whyUseful: Promotes gloss at high fire. Drives wollastonite crystallisation at saturation. Map to see CaO saturation zones and predict crystal matte development.

properties.label: SrO
properties.whatItIs: Strontium oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Similar to CaO but with a slightly softer melt. Useful as a safe barium substitute when satin/matte surfaces are desired without toxicity concerns.

properties.label: BaO
properties.whatItIs: Barium oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Promotes satin/matte finishes, high refractive index for visual depth. Toxic in raw/soluble form. Map to track where barium concentration exceeds safety limits.

properties.label: ZnO
properties.whatItIs: Zinc oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Crystal promoter — drives willemite (Zn₂SiO₄) formation. Brightens gloss, raises surface tension. Map to predict crystalline glaze potential.

properties.label: PbO
properties.whatItIs: Lead oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Extremely powerful low-fire flux with incomparable depth and brilliance. Toxic — historical use only. Map to ensure zero lead in functional ware.

properties.label: B₂O₃
properties.whatItIs: Boron oxide moles in UMF. Dual role: glass former AND flux.
properties.whyUseful: Lowers viscosity and COE. Enables low-fire glazes. Highly volatile above cone 6 — map to predict composition change from boron loss during firing.

properties.label: Fe₂O₃
properties.whatItIs: Iron oxide moles in UMF. Primary colorant with minor flux role.
properties.whyUseful: Amber/brown in oxidation, celadon green/tenmoku black in reduction. Map for iron saturation zones. Controls color in most traditional ceramic glazes.

properties.label: TiO₂
properties.whatItIs: Titanium dioxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Opacifier, promotes crystallisation (rutile needles). Provides warmth in colour (ivory tones). Map to find opacity thresholds.

properties.label: ZrO₂
properties.whatItIs: Zirconium dioxide moles in UMF. Strongest opacifier per mole.
properties.whyUseful: Increases viscosity. Used in commercial white glazes. Map for optimal opacification without stiffening the melt too much.

properties.label: SnO₂
properties.whatItIs: Tin dioxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Classic opacifier for tin glazes and majolica. Produces chrome-tin pinks when combined with Cr₂O₃. Map to compare efficiency vs ZrO₂.

properties.label: MnO
properties.whatItIs: Manganese (II) oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Purple/brown in oxidation. Metallic surface in heavy reduction. Map for concentration effects on color.

properties.label: MnO₂
properties.whatItIs: Manganese dioxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Stronger oxidiser form of manganese. Similar color effects to MnO but with different redox behavior.

properties.label: NiO
properties.whatItIs: Nickel oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Grey-green-brown. Mutes other colorants. Used as crystalline glaze seed. Map to control color suppression effects.

properties.label: CuO
properties.whatItIs: Cupric oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Green in oxidation, red in reduction (copper reds). Map to find optimal copper red chemistry — needs fluid alkali melt with low alumina.

properties.label: Cu₂O
properties.whatItIs: Cuprous oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Reduction form enabling copper-red glazes. The lower oxidation state produces colloidal copper particles that create the famous ox-blood and flambé effects.

properties.label: CoO
properties.whatItIs: Cobalt oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Strong, stable blue. Works in both oxidation and reduction atmospheres. Very powerful — map to avoid over-saturation (as little as 0.5% produces strong blue).

properties.label: Cr₂O₃
properties.whatItIs: Chromium oxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Forest green. Produces chrome-tin pinks with SnO₂. Volatile in some temperature ranges. Map to predict color interaction zones.

properties.label: P₂O₅
properties.whatItIs: Phosphorus pentoxide moles in UMF.
properties.whyUseful: Opalescence from calcium phosphate crystallisation (bone ash). Map to find the P₂O₅ + CaO sweet spot for chün/opal effects.

properties.label: Cone
properties.whatItIs: Firing cone number. Sets the temperature context for all temperature-dependent calculations.
properties.whyUseful: All viscosity, volatilisation, and crystal calculations depend on the firing temperature. When specified, uses exact Orton midpoint temperatures. When not specified, estimates from chemistry.

properties.label: R₂O:RO
properties.whatItIs: Alkali fraction of total flux. The fraction of the entire formula consisting of flux oxides. A high flux ratio (>0.35) means an aggressive, fluid melt; low (<0.20) means stiff and refractory.
properties.whyUseful: 1 = all alkali (fluid, craze-prone), 0 = all alkaline-earth (stiff, durable). This single number captures the fundamental balance between glass builders and glass breakers. Map to see which Stull chart regions produce properly melted glazes at your cone.

properties.label: SiO₂:Al₂O₃
properties.whatItIs: The Stull chart X/Y ratio — the primary diagonal axis of the original Stull chart. The master controller of surface texture.
properties.whyUseful: Ratios of 5–8 produce classic glossy glazes. 3–5: satin/matte. Below 3: dry, rough. Above 10: melt becomes unstable. One of the most important numbers in glaze chemistry.

properties.label: Total Flux Moles
properties.equation: Σ(Na₂O + K₂O + Li₂O + CaO + MgO + ZnO + BaO + SrO + PbO)
properties.whatItIs: Sum of all flux species moles. In a true UMF this is normalized to 1.0.
properties.whyUseful: Reveals how much melting power the glaze has. Higher = more fluid at temperature. Also useful for data quality checking — large deviations from 1.0 indicate approximated normalization.

properties.label: Thermal Exp. (COE)
properties.equation: Σ xᵢ·αᵢ (Appen additive model, 15 oxide-specific factors)
properties.whatItIs: Coefficient of thermal expansion — how much the glaze shrinks during cooling. THE #1 practical calculation in glaze chemistry.
properties.whyUseful: If COE(glaze) > COE(body), the glaze is under tension → crazing. COE(glaze) ≪ COE(body) → shivering. Mapping COE as a 3D surface instantly reveals safe compositional zones. Targets: earthenware ~70, stoneware ~55, porcelain ~45.

properties.label: R₂O : RO
properties.whatItIs: Whether fluxing is dominated by alkalis or alkaline earths.
properties.whyUseful: >1 = alkali-dominant (glossy, fluid, craze-prone). <1 = AE-dominant (stiffer, more durable, matte-leaning). Predicts an enormous amount about glaze character in a single number.

properties.label: Al₂O₃ / Flux
properties.whatItIs: Alumina per flux mole — since UMF normalizes flux to ~1.0, roughly equals the raw Al₂O₃ value.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = stiffer melt, more matte character. The key matting/stiffening control. Map to find where alumina saturation begins to matte the surface.

properties.label: NBO/T
properties.whatItIs: Non-bridging oxygens per tetrahedron. THE single most important structural parameter in glass science. 0 = fully polymerized like pure silica. 4 = fully depolymerized like olivine.
properties.whyUseful: Controls viscosity, chemical durability, crystal tendency, diffusion rate, and almost every physical property. Typical glazes: 0.5–2.0. Map it to see how glass structure changes across the Stull chart.

properties.label: Optical Basicity (Λ)
properties.whatItIs: Weighted-average electron donation to oxygen. The overall electron-donating ability of the glass.
properties.whyUseful: >0.6 = basic (modifier-like, fluid, more Fe²⁺ blue/green). <0.5 = acidic (durable, more Fe³⁺ brown). Controls iron redox ratio and color, sulfur solubility, and refractoriness.

properties.label: ASI (Alumina Saturation Index)
properties.whatItIs: Whether there's enough charge-compensating flux for all the alumina. Originally from igneous (Shand 1927), adapted for ceramic chemistry.
properties.whyUseful: <1 peralkaline (glossy, fluid), >1 peraluminous (matte, crystal-prone). The boundary at ASI = 1 is where many important glazing transitions happen — gloss/matte, durable/fragile.

properties.label: Flux Diversity
properties.whatItIs: Shannon entropy of the flux distribution. One of the most powerful predictive tools.
properties.whyUseful: Higher entropy = more diverse flux cocktail = more eutectic melting points = lower firing temp, wider range, smoother melt. A single-flux glaze (H=0) is stiff. A 5-flux diverse glaze (H≈1.6) melts easily with a wide working range.

properties.label: CaO:MgO
properties.whatItIs: Calcium share of Ca+Mg. The classic gloss-to-matte slider.
properties.whyUseful: 1 = all CaO (hard, bright gloss). 0 = all MgO (buttery, smooth matte). Map to find the transition zone for your ideal satin surface.

properties.label: Combined Alkali
properties.whatItIs: Total alkali content. The single biggest predictor of crazing.
properties.whyUseful: Combined alkali above 0.3 UMF moles almost always produces crazing on stoneware bodies. Map as a 3D surface to instantly see which compositional regions are safe vs dangerous.

properties.label: Na₂O:K₂O
properties.whatItIs: Soda-potash balance. A 50:50 blend creates the mixed alkali effect.
properties.whyUseful: Na₂O promotes brighter, more fluid melts and crystal-clear surfaces. K₂O gives softer, warmer character. Map to tune color response and surface character.

properties.label: Viscosity Index
properties.equation: Σ xᵢ·Vᵢ (Lakatos-type weighting: SiO₂→10, Al₂O₃→15, CaO→3, Na₂O→1, etc.)
properties.whatItIs: Quick stiffness ranking. Higher = stiffer melt.
properties.whyUseful: 3–5 = typical functional glaze range. Below 3 = running/pooling. Above 8 = dry, underfired. Map to predict glaze behavior without test tiles.

properties.label: Surface Tension
properties.equation: Σ(xᵢ·nC·FSᵢ) / Σ(xᵢ·nC) — Dietzel field strength values
properties.whatItIs: Average Dietzel field strength. Tendency of the melt surface to minimise area.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = crawling risk (glaze pulls away from edges and texture). Lower = wetting, leveling, spreading. ZnO-heavy glazes flag high. Critical for understanding crawling defects.

properties.label: Chem. Durability
properties.whatItIs: Chemical resistance ratio. Below 3 = poor (glass dissolves over time). 3–6 = adequate. Above 6 = laboratory glass grade.
properties.whyUseful: Food-safety baseline. Higher = more resistant to acid/alkali attack. Crude but directional — the fundamental measure of whether a glaze will survive daily use.

properties.label: Refractive Index
properties.whatItIs: How much the glaze bends light — the fundamental optical property.
properties.whyUseful: Higher n = more brilliant, deeper-looking surface. Lead glazes have very high n (why they look so rich). Boron and lithium lower n. Map to predict surface depth and brilliance.

properties.label: Density (g/cm³)
properties.equation: Σ(xᵢ·Mᵢ) / Σ(xᵢ·Vᵢ) — Appen molar volume method
properties.whatItIs: Physical density of the glass.
properties.whyUseful: Affects settling in the bucket, application thickness, visual weight, and gravity-driven flow. Lead/barium glazes are heaviest (~3.5+ g/cm³). Boron/lithium glazes are lightest (~2.3 g/cm³).

properties.label: Melt Fluidity
properties.whatItIs: Flow tendency, more nuanced than viscosity_index. Li₂O×3.0 vs MgO×0.6 makes a real difference.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = more flow, more leveling, but more risk of running. Important for layering — top coat should be more fluid than base coat.

properties.label: Molar Mass (g/mol)
properties.equation: M̄ = Σ(nᵢ·Mᵢ) / Σ(nᵢ) — IUPAC atomic weights
properties.whatItIs: Weighted-average formula weight of the composition.
properties.whyUseful: Heavier glazes (high PbO, BaO) are denser and more refractive. Lighter glazes (high Li₂O, B₂O₃) are more insulating. Useful for batch weight calculations.

properties.label: Acid Resistance
properties.whatItIs: Network-former / modifier ratio for acid resistance. The 'lemon juice test' proxy.
properties.whyUseful: Values > 5 = very acid-resistant (safe for citric food). < 2 = vulnerable. Al₂O₃ contributes 1.5× because it's particularly acid-resistant in glass networks.

properties.label: Melting Range (°C)
properties.equation: T_liquidus − T_solidus (estimated from flux diversity and alumina content)
properties.whatItIs: Temperature span between first melting and complete melting.
properties.whyUseful: Wider = more forgiving in the kiln (glazes that melt gradually). Narrower = sharper melting behavior. Related to eutectic behavior.

properties.label: Crawl Risk
properties.whatItIs: Bead-up / crawl tendency. Above ~50 = significant crawling risk.
properties.whyUseful: Crawling happens when high surface tension tries to minimize surface area but the melt is too viscous to re-level. ZnO-heavy glazes are flagged. Map to avoid problem zones.

properties.label: Craze Risk
properties.whatItIs: Thermal expansion mismatch. Positive = crazing (glaze in tension). Negative = compression fit (good).
properties.whyUseful: The functional potter's key metric. A single positive/negative number. Auto-adjusts body COE by cone range. Map to find exactly where the crazing boundary lies in compositional space.

properties.label: Leach Risk
properties.whatItIs: Alkali leaching propensity. How easily ions migrate into food/water.
properties.whyUseful: High leach risk = metallic taste, health concern. Both SiO₂ and Al₂O₃ must be adequate to prevent leaching. Flags lead, barium, copper with poor silica protection.

properties.label: COE Body Fit
properties.whatItIs: Absolute COE mismatch regardless of direction. Values below 5 are ideal.
properties.whyUseful: Above 10: either crazing (too high) or shivering (too low). Body COE auto-adjusts: earthenware ~70, stoneware ~55, porcelain ~45. Quick pass/fail for production.

properties.label: Matteness
properties.whatItIs: Composite predictor of matte surface development. Combines viscosity, surface tension, and density.
properties.whyUseful: Can crystals form before the surface smooths? Does the surface resist leveling? Does gravity pull it flat? Higher values predict more matte surfaces. <0.8 glossy, 0.8–1.2 satin, >1.2 matte.

properties.label: Boron Ratio
properties.whatItIs: What fraction of the glass network is boron.
properties.whyUseful: Low (<0.1) = minimal effect. Medium (0.1–0.3) = significant flux action. High (>0.3) = volatilization risk, phase separation tendency. Map to optimize boron usage.

properties.label: Comp. Entropy
properties.whatItIs: Total compositional complexity. More complex compositions tend to have lower melting points and wider working ranges (high-entropy alloy principle).
properties.whyUseful: Higher entropy = more complex = favours amorphous glass over crystal formation. Simple 3-oxide glazes are more predictable but less forgiving.

properties.label: Excess Alkali
properties.whatItIs: Peralkaline vs peraluminous boundary. How much free (uncompensated) alkali exists.
properties.whyUseful: >0 peralkaline (glossy, fluid, dangerous free alkali causing crazing, poor durability, leaching). <0 peraluminous (all alkali safely locked into alumina network). Zero = perfect balance. One of the simplest but most powerful diagnostic numbers.

properties.label: KNaO Equivalent
properties.whatItIs: All alkalis converted to a single equivalent number based on molar weight ratio. Na₂O-normalised alkali load.
properties.whyUseful: Different alkalis have different molecular weights but similar fluxing power. Gives a single number for total alkali effect, properly weighted across different alkali sources.

properties.label: Limit Conformance
properties.equation: 100 − penalty×40 (distance from Hesselberth/Stull UMF limits at firing cone)
properties.whatItIs: Whether the formula is within accepted compositional ranges. Auto-adjusts for low-fire (cone 06–4), mid-fire (cone 5–8), and high-fire (cone 9+).
properties.whyUseful: 100 = all oxides within standard limits. 0 = far outside. Map as a 3D landscape to see which Stull chart regions are 'normal' vs 'experimental'.

properties.label: Young's Modulus (GPa)
properties.equation: E = Σ xᵢ·Eᵢ — Makishima-Mackenzie additive model
properties.whatItIs: Elastic stiffness — resistance to elastic deformation. Typical glasses: 50–90 GPa.
properties.whyUseful: Stiffer glaze = harder, more scratch-resistant, but more brittle. Needed for all stress calculations. High-alumina glazes tend to be stiffer. Drives all other mechanical properties.

properties.label: Hardness (GPa)
properties.whatItIs: Vickers micro-hardness. Scratch and wear resistance.
properties.whyUseful: Important for tableware (cutlery marking), floor tiles, and functional ware. Higher = more scratch-resistant. Map to find the most durable surface compositions.

properties.label: Poisson Ratio
properties.equation: ν ≈ Σ xᵢ·νᵢ — additive estimate (0.17–0.27 for oxide glasses)
properties.whatItIs: Lateral-to-axial strain ratio. How much the material spreads sideways when compressed vertically.
properties.whyUseful: Affects crack propagation and stress distribution. Lower ν = more brittle fracture. Higher ν = more ductile response. Used in glaze stress calculations. 0.17–0.28 for glasses.

properties.label: Tg Estimate (°C)
properties.equation: Tg ≈ Σ xᵢ·Tg,ᵢ — Priven additive factors (SiO₂→730°C, Al₂O₃→900°C, B₂O₃→260°C, Na₂O→280°C, etc.)
properties.whatItIs: Glass transition temperature — where the glaze freezes from liquid into solid during cooling.
properties.whyUseful: Below Tg, stress is permanently locked in. High Tg = more thermal stress. Low Tg = more compliant during cooling = fewer defects. Critical for annealing and COE matching.

properties.label: Thermal Shock Resist.
properties.equation: H / (E × COE) — Hasselman figure of merit
properties.whatItIs: Combined figure of merit for resistance to rapid temperature changes.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = survives dunting, raku, oven-to-table, microwave, thermal cycling better. Captures interaction between strength, stiffness, and expansion. Essential for functional ware.

properties.label: Packing Density
properties.whatItIs: Atomic packing fraction. How efficiently atoms fill space.
properties.whyUseful: Tighter packing = harder, denser, more chemically durable glass. Drives Makishima-Mackenzie E and H calculations. Map to find the most durable compositional zones.

properties.label: Molar Refractivity
properties.equation: Rₘ = Σ xᵢ·Rᵢ — Lorentz-Lorenz ionic refractivity, 12-oxide table
properties.whatItIs: Total electronic polarisability of the composition.
properties.whyUseful: Drives both refractive index and dielectric constant via Clausius-Mossotti/Lorentz-Lorenz. Higher Rm = more brilliant optical response.

properties.label: Dielectric Constant
properties.whatItIs: Relative permittivity. Alkali-rich glasses: ε ≈ 6–10. Pure silica: ε ≈ 3.8.
properties.whyUseful: Microwave absorption driver. Higher ε = absorbs more microwave energy = gets hotter. Important for electronics substrates, spark plug insulators, and microwave safety.

properties.label: Mean Coord. #
properties.equation: Σ(xᵢ·nᵢ·CNᵢ) / Σ(xᵢ·nᵢ) — Si→4, Al→4, Na→6, Ca→8, B→3.5, etc.
properties.whatItIs: Average coordination number. Higher CN = more rigid network.
properties.whyUseful: Lower = more 'open' network (softer, more reactive). Higher = more tightly packed (harder, more durable). Tracks with density and hardness. Drive of the floppy→rigid topological transition.

properties.label: Constraints/Atom
properties.whatItIs: Topological constraint count (Phillips-Thorpe theory). Magic number = 3.0 (Maxwell isostatic threshold).
properties.whyUseful: <3.0 'floppy' (good glass former, easy to melt, soft). >3.0 'stressed-rigid' (hard, brittle, prone to cracking). At exactly 3.0 = most stable glass. The physics behind why glazes melt.

properties.label: Q⁴ Fraction
properties.whatItIs: Fully-connected SiO₄ tetrahedra. Proportion with 4 bridging oxygens.
properties.whyUseful: Higher Q⁴ = hard, durable, chemically resistant glass (like pure fused silica). Low Q⁴ = soft, soluble, easily attacked. Map to predict the most durable compositional regions.

properties.label: Q² Fraction
properties.whatItIs: Chain-forming SiO₄ — tetrahedra with only 2 bridging oxygens.
properties.whyUseful: High Q² = chains instead of 3D network = plastic flowing melt, poor chemical durability. Important for understanding why some glazes run — their structure is dominated by chains.

properties.label: Liquidus (°C)
properties.whatItIs: Temperature where the last crystal dissolves — above this, the melt is fully liquid.
properties.whyUseful: Must fire above liquidus for complete melting. Below = residual crystals (sometimes desired for texture). Distance between firing temp and liquidus determines crystal content.

properties.label: Devit. Index
properties.whatItIs: Devitrification tendency. CaO → wollastonite, ZnO → willemite, TiO₂ → rutile. Low entropy = one phase dominates = crystals form easily.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = more crystal-prone on cooling. Map to avoid devitrification in functional ware, or promote it in crystal glazes.

properties.label: Hydration Energy
properties.whatItIs: Glass hydration susceptibility — thermodynamic durability measure.
properties.whyUseful: More negative = thermodynamically more susceptible to water dissolution. Predicts whether it WILL dissolve given enough time (vs kinetic durability which predicts how fast).

properties.label: Modifier Fraction
properties.whatItIs: Network modifier share. 0 = pure former, 1 = pure modifier.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = more fluid melt, lower Tg, more crystal-prone but easier to melt. Typical glazes: 0.3–0.5.

properties.label: Fragility Index (m)
properties.whatItIs: Strong vs fragile glass classification (Angell). m≈20 strong/SiO₂-like, gradual softening. m≈80+ fragile, sharp Tg.
properties.whyUseful: Strong glasses (m≈20) change viscosity gradually — very forgiving. Fragile glasses (m≈80+) have sharp transitions — narrow firing window, sensitive to temperature.

properties.label: Fe²⁺ Fraction
properties.equation: ~(Λ − 0.3) × 1.25 — linear mapping from optical basicity, clamped 0–1
properties.whatItIs: Predicted Fe²⁺/Fe-total ratio from composition alone (before firing).
properties.whyUseful: Fe²⁺ → blue/green (celadon). Fe³⁺ → amber/brown. Higher basicity shifts toward Fe²⁺. Predicts color shift from composition alone — the ratio depends on both atmosphere AND glass composition.

properties.label: Firing Temp (°C)
properties.whatItIs: Peak firing temperature from cone or estimated from chemistry.
properties.whyUseful: The thermal context for all other temperature-dependent calculations. When cone is specified, uses exact Orton midpoints. When not, estimates from chemistry to predict what cone an unfamiliar recipe needs.

properties.label: Viscosity (log Pa·s)
properties.equation: log₁₀(η) = A + B/(T − C) — VFT / Giordano-Russell-Dingwell model
properties.whatItIs: Full Vogel-Fulcher-Tammann melt viscosity at firing temperature. THE master property.
properties.whyUseful: 3–5 = runny like honey. 6–8 = stiff but flowing. 9–12 = effectively frozen. Controls flow, healing, defects, everything. Captures the highly non-linear temperature dependence that simple indices miss.

properties.label: Liquidus Overshoot
properties.whatItIs: Whether you're firing above or below the liquidus.
properties.whyUseful: Positive = fully molten (clean gloss). Negative = underfired (crystals remain, texture). Near zero = right at the melting boundary (interesting surface effects).

properties.label: Working Range (°C)
properties.whatItIs: Temperature span over which the glaze is actively flowing. Typical: 200–600°C.
properties.whyUseful: Wider = more forgiving (off by 20°C and still get a good result). Narrow = must hit exact temperature. Map to find compositions that are kiln-friendly.

properties.label: Heatwork Excess
properties.whatItIs: Whether the chemistry requires more or less heat than the target cone delivers.
properties.whyUseful: Positive = underfired at target cone. Negative = may run. Zero = perfect match. Helps match glaze chemistry to kiln capability.

properties.label: Volatilisation Index
properties.whatItIs: Evaporation risk at firing temperature. B₂O₃ is the most volatile ceramic oxide.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = more volatile oxides lost → composition changes in the kiln → unpredictable results. At cone 10, significant boron escapes. Important for kiln atmosphere and neighbor contamination.

properties.label: Fe Color (Oxidation)
properties.whatItIs: Iron colour intensity in oxidation (electric kiln). 0 = no iron colour, 10 = saturated iron brown.
properties.whyUseful: Color depends not just on iron amount but on dilution in the glass network. High SiO₂ + Al₂O₃ dilute the color. Amber→brown spectrum.

properties.label: Fe Color (Reduction)
properties.equation: min(10, Fe/(SiO₂ + Al₂O₃) × 30 × Ca_boost) — Ca_boost ×1.5 when CaO > 0.3
properties.whatItIs: Iron colour intensity in reduction (gas kiln). Celadon→tenmoku spectrum. CaO boost captures the classic tenmoku mechanism.
properties.whyUseful: In reduction, Fe²⁺ dominates → green (celadon) at low iron, dark brown/black (tenmoku) at high iron. High CaO + high Fe + reduction = oil-spot and hare's fur effects.

properties.label: Mixed Alkali Effect
properties.equation: 4 × x_Na × x_K — parabolic maximum at 50:50 Na:K
properties.whatItIs: Anomalous transport behavior at mixed alkali compositions. Maximum at 50:50 Na:K.
properties.whyUseful: At 50:50, ionic conductivity drops dramatically (Day 1976). This means: lower leaching (good for durability), unusual viscosity behavior, and different color development.

properties.label: Boron N₄ Fraction
properties.equation: R / (R + B₂O₃) — where R = total modifier charge (Dell-Bray model)
properties.whatItIs: Tetrahedral [BO₄] fraction vs trigonal [BO₃]. BO₄ strengthens network, BO₃ weakens it.
properties.whyUseful: Below ~16 mol% modifier → boron stays BO₃ (weakening). Above → converts to BO₄ (strengthening). Determines whether boron helps or hurts your glass.

properties.label: Colorant / Flux
properties.whatItIs: Effective colorant concentration normalized by flux content.
properties.whyUseful: Same 2% iron in stiff high-fire vs fluid low-fire glaze produces very different colors. Higher = more saturated colour, but too high = metallic surfaces, pinholing.

properties.label: Food Safety Score
properties.equation: Composite 0–1 score: −0.4 for PbO, −0.2 for BaO>0.15, −0.1 for CuO>0.1, −0.1 for Cr₂O₃>0.05, −0.2 for durability<3
properties.whatItIs: Multi-criteria food safety screening. 1.0 = passes all checks. <0.6 = fails one or more.
properties.whyUseful: Quick screening for functional dinnerware glazes. Checks lead (FDA zero tolerance), excess barium, excess copper, excess chromium, and adequate silica-to-alkali durability.

properties.label: Microwave Safety
properties.whatItIs: Microwave absorption risk. 1.0 = safe (no absorbers). 0 = problematic.
properties.whyUseful: Fe, Mn, Ni, Cu, Co absorb 2.45 GHz microwave radiation → hot spots. Map for microwave-safe dinnerware design.

properties.label: Opacity Predictor
properties.whatItIs: Opacification strength. Each opacifier weighted by effectiveness per mole.
properties.whyUseful: 0 = transparent, 1 = opaque. ZrO₂ and SnO₂ are strongest. TiO₂ contributes via crystal formation. P₂O₅ via phase separation (opalescence). Map to design opacity gradients.

properties.label: Robustness
properties.equation: max(∂COE, ∂Visc, ∂NBO per ±0.01 Δoxide) — numerical Jacobian over 10 oxides
properties.whatItIs: Maximum property swing from small composition changes. The 'production reliability' metric.
properties.whyUseful: Lower = more forgiving. Higher = sensitive to weighing errors. Studio potters with small scales want low robustness. Factories with precision dosing can tolerate higher.

properties.label: Critical Oxide Impact
properties.equation: max COE sensitivity at ±5% — for each of 10 oxides
properties.whatItIs: Which single ingredient causes the largest property swing if mis-measured.
properties.whyUseful: Tells you which oxide to weigh most carefully. If Na₂O shows up, feldspar measurement errors will cause the most crazing variation. Prioritize accuracy for this material.

properties.label: Error Width (COE)
properties.equation: √(Σ(∂COE/∂xᵢ)²·σᵢ²) — Taylor first-order error propagation at ±2% relative error
properties.whatItIs: The ±spread in COE from ±2% weighing error on ALL oxides simultaneously.
properties.whyUseful: If error_width is 3.0, your COE of 55 is actually 52–58. If this overlaps body COE, some batches will craze while others won't. Critical for production consistency.

properties.label: Total Colorant
properties.equation: Σ(Fe₂O₃ + TiO₂ + MnO + NiO + CuO + CoO + Cr₂O₃)
properties.whatItIs: Sum of all transition metal oxide moles.
properties.whyUseful: Quick measure of colour load. Above ~0.5 mol = saturated, dark. Below 0.05 = nearly colorless. High total = dark/opaque; very low = clear/white base.

properties.label: Fe:Ti
properties.whatItIs: Iron share of Fe+Ti. 1 = all iron (warm brown). 0 = all titanium (cream/ivory).
properties.whyUseful: Pure iron → red/brown/black. Pure titanium → opacity. Mixtures → complex amber-gold-russet colors. Map to predict iron-titanium color interaction.

properties.label: Phase Sep. Index
properties.whatItIs: Phase-separation / immiscibility likelihood. High values (>20) suggest opalescence potential.
properties.whyUseful: Phase separation produces opalescent blue effects (chün, jun, opal) with slow cooling. Al₂O₃ strongly suppresses it. Boron promotes it. The key calculation for chün glaze design.

properties.label: Wollastonite Sat.
properties.whatItIs: CaSiO₃ crystal potential. (SiO₂ − 6·Al₂O₃) = 'free silica' not tied in feldspar phases.
properties.whyUseful: >0.5 = crystal matte development begins. Core calculation for predicting calcium matte surfaces. Classic cone 6–10 crystal matte mechanism.

properties.label: Zn Crystal Index
properties.whatItIs: Willemite (Zn₂SiO₄) crystal likelihood. ZnO squared because crystallisation scales with concentration² (nucleation kinetics).
properties.whyUseful: >0.05 = zinc-crystal texture potential. The basis of macro-crystalline glazes. Al₂O₃ inhibits zinc crystal formation.

properties.label: Devit. Resistance
properties.whatItIs: Devitrification safety. Inverse of devit_index.
properties.whyUseful: 100 = very safe from unwanted crystals (clean glass). 0 = highly prone. For functional ware, aim >60. For decorative crystal glazes, aim <30.

properties.label: Tenmoku Index
properties.whatItIs: Tenmoku/iron-saturate potential. >40 = tenmoku territory (oil-spot, hare's fur, mirror-black).
properties.whyUseful: Needs high Fe₂O₃ (0.5–1.0+), CaO as primary flux, moderate alumina, and reduction atmosphere. Map to find the sweet spot for your iron source and clay body.

properties.label: Celadon Index
properties.whatItIs: Proximity to ideal celadon composition (SiO₂≈4.0, Al₂O₃≈0.4, CaO≈0.6, Fe₂O₃≈0.1).
properties.whyUseful: Values >70 = excellent celadon potential. Iron must be LOW (~0.1 mol). Most specific glaze type — requires very precise chemistry. For jade-green reduction glazes.

properties.label: Shino Index
properties.whatItIs: Shino character potential. Na₂O-dominant, feldspathic character.
properties.whyUseful: Values >50 = strong shino character (carbon trapping, warm blushes, orange-peel texture). Classic shino uses nepheline syenite or soda feldspar — very high Na₂O, low alumina, minimal potash.

properties.label: Copper Red Potential
properties.whatItIs: Chemistry-only copper red likelihood (still needs reduction atmosphere).
properties.whyUseful: Copper reds need: CuO present, fluid alkali-rich melt (low viscosity → copper colloid formation), low alumina. Boron helps (increases fluidity). Chemistry provides the canvas; atmosphere is the final ingredient.

properties.label: Opal Potential
properties.whatItIs: Bone-ash opalescence. Ca₃(PO₄)₂ crystal formation from P₂O₅ + CaO.
properties.whyUseful: Blue-white opalescence in slow cooling. Values >30 = significant effect. Needs BOTH P₂O₅ and CaO. Al₂O₃ inhibits crystallisation. Classic milky-white to blue chün effects.

properties.label: Softening Point (°C)
properties.equation: T at log₁₀(η) = 6.6 — VFT inversion (ASTM C338 Littleton softening point)
properties.whatItIs: Glass starts to deform under its own weight. Above this, the glaze is moving.
properties.whyUseful: Below this temperature the glaze is rigid solid. Above it, it starts to sag and flow. Critical lower bound of the firing window.

properties.label: Annealing Point (°C)
properties.equation: T at log₁₀(η) = 12.0 — VFT inversion (ASTM C336)
properties.whatItIs: Stress relaxation in minutes. Top of the annealing range.
properties.whyUseful: Hold here during cooling to relieve thermal stress. Important for thick glaze applications, tiles, and sculpture. Internal strain dissipates within minutes at this temperature.

properties.label: Strain Point (°C)
properties.equation: T at log₁₀(η) = 13.5 — VFT inversion (ASTM C336)
properties.whatItIs: Stress relaxation in hours — strain is effectively permanent below this. The 'point of no return'.
properties.whyUseful: Thermal gradients existing below this point are permanently locked in. Rapid cooling below strain point causes warping, cracking, or residual stress.

properties.label: Flow Point (°C)
properties.whatItIs: Glaze is fully fluid and flowing freely. Maximum fluidity temperature.
properties.whyUseful: Firing above this produces running and pooling. Some glazes (crystalline, ash) need to reach this; functional glazes should be below. The upper working threshold.

properties.label: Bulk Modulus (GPa)
properties.whatItIs: Resistance to uniform compression. Typical: 30–50 GPa.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = harder to compress = less compressible. Important for understanding hydrostatic pressure response (autoclave testing, deep-water applications). Connects to density under pressure and impact resistance.

properties.label: Shear Modulus (GPa)
properties.whatItIs: Resistance to shape change — sliding/twisting deformation.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = resists sliding deformation. Controls crack deflection behavior. Combined with K, defines the complete elastic response. Relevant to surface wear and abrasion resistance.

properties.label: Fracture Toughness (MPa√m)
properties.whatItIs: Crack propagation resistance. Typical: 0.5–1.0 MPa·√m.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = tougher. A chipped rim resists further damage. The glaze's ability to stop a crack once it starts. Important for functional ceramics that take impacts.

properties.label: Brittleness (µm⁻¹/²)
properties.whatItIs: Tendency to chip. The ratio of hardness to toughness. Typical: 5–10 µm⁻¹.
properties.whyUseful: Lower = safer for functional ware. Higher = chips from utensil impact. For tableware want moderate hardness (scratch-resistant) combined with high toughness (chip-resistant).

properties.label: Reduced Tg (Tg/Tliq)
properties.whatItIs: Turnbull's glass-forming criterion. How close Tg is to the melting point.
properties.whyUseful: >0.67 = excellent glass former (very hard to crystallize). <0.60 = marginal (crystallises easily on cooling). Critical for crystalline glaze design — LOW Trg to grow crystals, HIGH Trg for clean glass.

properties.label: Hrubý Parameter
properties.whatItIs: Glass stability metric. Resistance to crystallization.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = more stable glass (stays clear during cooling). Lower = narrow stability window = crystal-prone. Combined with cooling rate, predicts whether you get clean glass or unwanted crystals.

properties.label: Crit. Cooling Rate (°C/hr)
properties.whatItIs: Minimum cooling rate needed to prevent crystallization.
properties.whyUseful: Low Rc = can cool slowly and stay glassy. High Rc = must crash-cool. Crystal glaze artists want HIGH Rc (grow crystals by cooling slowly). Functional potters want LOW Rc.

properties.label: Glaze Stress (MPa)
properties.whatItIs: Actual biaxial thermal stress in the glaze film. Positive = tensile = crazing. Negative = compressive = good (up to a point).
properties.whyUseful: Goes beyond simple COE comparison by incorporating Young's modulus (stiffness), Poisson's ratio (lateral strain), and Tg (where stresses lock in). Professional-grade craze prediction. Quantifies the stress, not just risk.

properties.label: Stress Ratio (σ/τ)
properties.whatItIs: Applied stress vs glaze tensile strength. >1 = craze guaranteed. <0.5 = safe. 0.5–1 = marginal.
properties.whyUseful: The most complete crazing predictor in the system — accounts for the glaze's actual strength, not just its COE. Combines stress magnitude with material capability.

properties.label: Pinhole Risk Index
properties.whatItIs: Gas entrapment tendency. Pinholes: #1 studio defect. CO₂ from carbonates (whiting, dolomite) can't escape viscous melt.
properties.whyUseful: High viscosity + high carbonate flux + narrow working range = worst case. Map to redesign problem glazes. Pinholes form when gas can't escape through a viscous melt.

properties.label: Bubble Risk Index
properties.whatItIs: Trapped bubble/blister retention. Different from pinholes — bubbles from pre-existing gas (air, water vapor).
properties.whyUseful: High Q⁴ = tightly cross-linked network = gas can't diffuse through. Combined with high viscosity = sealed bubbles. Map to predict blistering glazes.

properties.label: Healing Index
properties.whatItIs: Self-healing surface flow. Can surface defects flow out?
properties.whyUseful: Higher = better self-healing. Low viscosity + low surface tension = defects (pin marks, crawl patches, edge pulls) flow out and smooth over. Map for compositions producing flawless surfaces.

properties.label: Liquidus Field (Code)
properties.equation: CAS ternary boundary classification (all fluxes projected onto CaO equivalent). Returns: 1=Cristobalite, 2=Mullite, 3=Anorthite, 4=Wollastonite, 5=Tridymite
properties.whatItIs: Primary crystallisation field — which crystal forms first during cooling.
properties.whyUseful: Cristobalite → gloss with potential craze. Mullite → tough, matte. Anorthite → balanced. Wollastonite → crystal matte. Controls surface texture, opacity, and thermal behavior.

properties.label: Eutectic Distance
properties.equation: min(√(ΔSi² + ΔAl² + ΔCa²)) over 5 CAS ternary eutectics (1170–1587°C)
properties.whatItIs: Distance to nearest eutectic trough in the CaO-Al₂O₃-SiO₂ system.
properties.whyUseful: Lower = closer to a low-melting eutectic = easier to melt = more reliable. Eutectic compositions have interesting textures from competing crystal phases. Map to find the easiest-to-melt regions.

properties.label: Abbe Number (Vd)
properties.whatItIs: Optical dispersion — how much refractive index varies with wavelength.
properties.whyUseful: Lower Abbe = more chromatic dispersion = more 'fire' and light-splitting. PbO and TiO₂ increase dispersion. High-silica = less dispersion. Relevant for decorative effects.

properties.label: Optical Bandgap (eV)
properties.whatItIs: UV absorption edge — how deep into the visible spectrum the glass absorbs.
properties.whyUseful: Lower bandgap → absorbs more visible light → may yellow or develop body color. Higher bandgap → more transparent. Important for understanding why some 'clear' glazes come out tinted.

properties.label: Luster Index (%R)
properties.whatItIs: Normal-incidence reflectance. The actual percentage of light bouncing off the surface — shininess.
properties.whyUseful: Soda-lime glass: ~3.5%. Lead glass: 5–10%+. Higher = shinier, more lustrous. This is what your eye sees as 'gloss'. Map to find the most brilliant compositional regions.

properties.label: Ionic Conductivity (log σ)
properties.whatItIs: Room-temperature ionic conductivity from mobile alkali ions.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = more mobile ions = more leaching, corrosion, electrolytic degradation. Important for food safety (mobile ions = leaching), electronics (want low), and understanding why some glazes discolor over time.

properties.label: Loss Tangent (tan δ)
properties.equation: tan δ = σ / (2πf·ε₀·εᵣ) at f = 2.45 GHz (microwave frequency)
properties.whatItIs: Dielectric loss at microwave frequency. How much energy the glaze absorbs and converts to heat.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = hotter in the microwave. For microwave-safe dinnerware, want very low tan δ. A cup of coffee gets hot — but so does the glazed mug? That's high loss tangent.

properties.label: Pred. L* (Oxidation)
properties.whatItIs: Predicted lightness in oxidation atmosphere. Beer-Lambert absorption model — each colorant darkens proportionally.
properties.whyUseful: Iron has the biggest effect (square root because it saturates). Map as a landscape to see the 'dark zones' of the Stull chart. Approximate — atmosphere, cooling, thickness all matter.

properties.label: Pred. a* (Oxidation)
properties.whatItIs: Predicted red/green axis in CIE color space.
properties.whyUseful: Iron pushes toward warm reds/browns. Copper and chromium push toward green. Manganese adds slight warmth. Directional colour guide for warm vs cool tones.

properties.label: Pred. b* (Oxidation)
properties.whatItIs: Predicted yellow/blue axis in CIE color space.
properties.whyUseful: Iron and titanium push toward warm yellows. Cobalt pushes strongly toward blue (largest coefficient). Manganese adds warmth. Map for yellow/amber vs blue tones.

properties.label: Soak Benefit Index
properties.equation: |B/(T_fire − C)²| × 500 — VFT slope at firing temperature
properties.whatItIs: Value of holding at peak temperature (soaking). The derivative of the VFT curve at firing temp.
properties.whyUseful: Steep VFT slope = every extra minute of soak produces significant viscosity reduction — soaking is highly beneficial. If flat, soaking does little. Tells you whether to hold at peak or save fuel.

properties.label: Crystal Window (°C)
properties.whatItIs: Temperature range during cooling where crystals can nucleate and grow.
properties.whyUseful: Wider = more time for crystals (crystalline glaze artists want wide). Narrow = less chance of unwanted devitrification (functional potters want narrow). Map to design firing schedules.

properties.label: Thermal Cond. (W/m·K)
properties.equation: λ = Σ xᵢ·λᵢ — additive model, 12-oxide table
properties.whatItIs: Rate of heat transfer through the glaze. Typical: 0.8–1.5 W/m·K.
properties.whyUseful: Lower = more insulating (coffee stays hot longer). Higher = better heat spreading (fewer thermal gradients → fewer thermal shock cracks). Map to design insulating vs heat-spreading surfaces.

properties.label: Specific Heat (J/g·K)
properties.whatItIs: Heat capacity per gram. Typical: 0.7–1.1 J/g·K.
properties.whyUseful: Higher Cp = more energy to heat/cool = slower temperature changes in the kiln. Affects firing cost, cooling rate, and thermal shock response.

properties.label: Thermal Diffusivity (mm²/s)
properties.whatItIs: How fast heat penetrates the material. Typical: 0.4–0.8 mm²/s.
properties.whyUseful: Higher = temperature equilibrates faster through thickness → fewer thermal gradients → less warping/cracking. Lower = surface heats while interior stays cold → thermal shock risk.

properties.label: Redox Buffer Capacity
properties.equation: Σ nᵢ·Δzᵢ for polyvalent ions: Fe(1), Mn(2), Cu(1), Cr(1), Co(1), Ti(1)
properties.whatItIs: Total electron-exchange capacity. How much atmosphere variation the glaze can absorb.
properties.whyUseful: High = colour stable across firing variation (atmosphere changes absorbed). Low = sensitive to kiln atmosphere (intentional for effects like copper reds). For consistent production want moderate buffer. For artistic variation, low buffer = more character.

mathematicalFoundations.equation: Properties depending on other computed properties

walkFeatures.name: UMF Delta Display
walkFeatures.description: Click two points on the Stull chart to see the exact oxide-by-oxide difference between them.
walkFeatures.purpose: Shows which oxides are responsible for property differences between two formulas.

walkFeatures.name: Interpolation Path
walkFeatures.description: Draws a virtual line between two compositions with a slider that walks along it, computing every Z-axis value at intermediate points.
walkFeatures.purpose: Answer 'what would happen if I moved 30% toward recipe B?' without mixing and firing test tiles.

walkFeatures.name: Recipe Suggestions
walkFeatures.description: Given a target UMF point, suggests real material combinations that achieve that composition.
walkFeatures.purpose: Bridges theory and practice: the Stull chart shows WHAT you want, this shows HOW to make it.

walkFeatures.name: Wet Blend
walkFeatures.description: Simulates physically mixing two glazes at any ratio, computing the resulting UMF plus all 133 properties on the blended composition.
walkFeatures.purpose: Discover that a 70:30 blend produces better COE match than either glaze alone.
